title: Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (PXF) & Glaucoma Capsulare
summary: PXF is a common, but easily missed, cause of secondary glaucoma. It is a systemic condition characterized by whitish dandruff-like material deposited in the eye and various internal organs, often leading to a more severe clinical course than POAG.

sections.title: Defining PXF: Names and Origins
sections.content: PXF is a common, but easily missed, cause of 2° glaucoma. The term was originally chosen to distinguish it from ‘true’ exfoliation syndrome, in which heat or infrared radiation caused damage to the lens capsule (e.g. in glass blowers). Confusingly, this distinction has become blurred, with PXF increasingly being referred to as exfoliation syndrome.

sections.title: Biological Composition & Associations
content: Exact nature is unclear but includes abnormal elastic microfibrils, BM material, and glycosaminoglycans.
Small studies suggest association with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease.
Possible link via elevation of plasma homocysteine levels.
Emerging evidence suggests screening for treatable conditions such as asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in primary care.

sections.title: The LOXL1 Genetic Link
content: Strongly associated with a single nucleotide polymorphism of the lysyl oxidase-like 1 (LOXL1) gene.

sections.title: Risk Factors
content: Ethnicity: North European (Finnish, Icelandic); Mediterranean (Cretan); possibly any population in which it is carefully looked for.

sections.title: Clinical Features: Eye Exam Findings
content: Dandruff-like material on pupillary border and anterior lens capsule (centrally and peripherally with a clear intermediate zone).
Iridodonesis/phacodonesis (NB risk of zonulodialysis during cataract surgery).
Pigment and pseudoexfoliative material on the endothelium (PXF endotheliopathy).

rows: Irregular deposition in the trabeculum and anterior to Schwalbe’s line (Sampaolesi’s line)
Usually open but may be narrow

sections.title: Glaucoma Capsulare: PXF Glaucoma
content: Glaucoma occurs in up to 25% of patients with PXF (up to 10-fold increased risk).
Disease course is more severe than POAG.

branches: Open angle: deposition of PXF material and pigment in the trabecular meshwork.
Narrow angle (rare): weak zonules with anterior movement of the lens-iris diaphragm; PS.

sections.title: Clinical Presentation of Glaucoma
sections.content: Features include those of PXF (see E Clinical features, p. 400), increased IOP (iIOP), disc changes, and field defects as for POAG (see E Primary open-angle glaucoma, pp. 390–1).

rows: As for POAG, but generally less effective; greater role for miotics (e.g. pilocarpine).
Particularly effective early on; >50% failure rate by 5y.
Similar efficacy to ALT, but less destructive and repeatable (consider using lower power settings in PXF).
Higher complication rate, but similar overall success to trabeculectomy in POAG.
